title: Why do we continue to nerf mages with point-and-click abilities, but make mobile assassins?
body:
It almost feels as if Riot does not want us to have a champion with an answer to mobility. We get {{champion:245}}  that can free form dash AND teleport to any target he attacks, but people like {{champion:13}} get shafted into a new skill shot that makes him unable to compete with it. {{champion:45}} gets half his kit changed because of play in LCS, yet {{champion:7}} has been EVERYWHERE since the beginning of time.  She even still has a point-and-click! How can you pass up high damage, CC, and 4 possible teleports on low cooldowns? You don't.  Hell, soon {{champion:4}}  will be changed to have some dumb gimmick where if you gold card you have to click W and toss it in a line or something like that. Can we get some champions that make assassins think twice about going in? I feel like {{champion:90}} {{champion:19}} {{champion:44}} {{champion:1}} are some of the last point and clicks in the game, but they have all been either nerfed or underplayed due to low mobility. 

This is mostly just me venting but I would like to know an answer. Are we doing away with old designed abilities, or are there other reasons for it. I want to hear the philosophy. I hope Riot responds as well.

Now that I am talking about point and click anyways, it has little to no counterplay. Either stay out of range, or get hit. No one (no one intelligent, at least) is arguing that skillshots don't offer more counterplay. The problem is that point-and-click is the most reliable way to deal with high mobility champions, and it is steadily being phased out of the game.

The better question isn't "do skill shots offer more counterplay", but instead, "do skill shots offer _better_ counterplay".

The answer to that is complicate and dependent on individual champions.
Is it better for counterplay to have every ability a skill shot? No, it is not, that is instead limiting design and removing a counterplay against mobility based champions.

If point-and-click abilities are removed from League of Legends entirely, it would be a bad sign for the game as the design team has begun limiting themselves and I suspect players would begin leaving, especially players on the east coast that have much higher ping than players on the west coast.

So far Riot has stated that they have no plans on removing point-and-click abilities entirely from the game. I would like them to pull back on the initiative on changes earlier champion's point-and-clicks into skill shots without a full rework, or even adding new champions (that are balanced) that are primarily point-and-click based with low mobility.
Guess what has no counterplay without point-and-clicks?

Because point-and-click abilities are, by their nature, harder to balance than skill shots. With the former, theres a lot less tuning options. You can hit the numbers, or you can hit the range. If its skill shot based, you have more avenues to adjust. Missile width, missile speed, range, damage, etc. Plus, point-and-click has the inherent frustration of zoning that comes with it. Everyone's experienced it with Annie. Once she has her stun up, there becomes an area around her where you don't want to enter, simply because you'll be stunned and there's nothing you can do about it.

DOTA is statistically more balanced than league (greater hero variety in pro play, less snowballing due to tiny initial leads, more team comps possible with different lane assignments), yet 90% of skills are either point and click or instant AOE. It also happens that mobility in DOTA is actually a huge tradeoff and mobile heroes either require a crap ton of gold to not suck or have very low damage; the heroes that are both mobile and have high base damage are usually pick or ban just like League (surprise, surprise, surprise).

It also makes a considerable difference that items in DOTA are just as, if not more important, than in League. Does your hero have low mobility? Get Yasha and its upgrades. Are you a squishy and want to be safe, but don't want to build tanky? Get Shadow Blade. Lack hard CC? There's items for that too!

I'm a Dota main, and you both have been away for a while. ;) Roughly half the strength heros are carries (Wraith King, Alchemist, Bristleback, Kunkka, Huskar, etc.). 

AM is primarily picked for farm speed; he's a lot more like {{champion:119}} than {{champion:96}} in that way. Basically, you can get six-slotted when their team's carry is 4-slotted. Also to counter a lot of the intelligence carries and medusa...

Highest pro ban rates for this patch are:

* Undying (immobile)
* QoP (highly mobile)
* IO (mobility enabler)
* Gyro (immobile)
* Broodmother (somewhat mobile; only boosted move speed, but spammable stealth)
* Visage (immobile)
* Viper (immobile AND super slow)
* Shadow Fiend (immobile)

You don't ban mobile heros because of their mobility, you pick silences and hard cc.  Of the mobile heros banned:

* QoP is banned because of simultaneous assassin and teamfight threat, which are both highly valued now.
* IO for his ability to make one carry a super duper carry.
* Broodmother because she's the easiest counter to a team that lacks good AoE clear.

The mobility is an important part of their kit, but it isn't the part that makes them banworthy. With the exception of IO sometimes, in some teams.

DOTA has less snowballing because of itemization and shutdown gold. If you played jungle before, you might have found that even after camping your 0-3 feeding top and making them 2-3 doesn't actually help them come back, and the minute you leave, they're dead again. Why? Because the enemy top already had the first mover advantage and snowballed their kill advantage into an EXP and item advantage, which allows them to CS and zone better, which allows them an even bigger EXP and item advantage... etc etc. In DOTA, if you gank the enemy side lane solo twice, you're giving your lane shutdown gold AND taking gold away from the enemy, while your solo laner doesn't have that much gold to lose since he was already feeding, so he comes out even again despite the enemy's previous snowballing.

 In addition, item power is nonlinear and increasing; bigger items are both more gold efficient and slot efficient, so in league you can't really build some cheap mid-game items to catch up the way you can in DOTA; cheap mid-game items are actually for snowballing even harder.

And statistically, a 1000 gold advantage at 10 minutes is a bigger deal in league than in DOTA (the team with the advantage wins more often).
